artist: Norbertine von Bresslern-Roth; Woodcut Society, Kansas City, Missouri
creditline: Gift of Marla J. Kinney in celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts
description: three stalking black panthers, moving diagonally across picture plane, casting grey shadows; moon in URC; green and grey grass with wavy lines; black border around image; printed inscription on back of mount
marks:
Signature, Inscription and Edition

on back, in  LRC below image, in pencil: [Bresslern-Roth.]
provenance: [Davidson Galleries, Seattle, until 2007; sold to Kinney]; Marla Kinney, Minneapolis (2007-15); given to MIA.
text: A participant in the Vienna Secession exhibitions, Norbertine von Bresslern-Roth was a skilled animal painter and accomplished printmaker. Her innovative woodcuts and linocuts were both influential and deceivingly simple—translating the appearance and behaviors of animals into forceful graphics full of energy and movement. In Phantoms, Bresslern-Roth represents three black panthers hunting silently in the moonlight. The figures’ dark silhouettes, which stand out against the cool green grass, capture the panthers’ stealthy power and chilling elegance, and their giant formless shadows evoke the phantoms that haunt children’s dreams.
title: Phantoms
